title: 108_s2932
content: The Act may be cited as the "Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Act of 2004". Congress acknowledges the distinguished service of Senator Mark O. Hatfield and Congresswoman Elizabeth Furse, recognizing their significant impact on the relationship with Native Americans. They have been advocates for Native American and Alaska Native rights, promoting tribal self-governance. Programs in their names aim to promote excellence in tribal government. In this Act, key terms defined include Board, eligible individual, Foundation, Fund, Institute, and institution of higher education. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "State" includes various regions such as states, territories, and commonwealths. Establishment of the Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation. The Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation is established as an independent entity in the Executive branch with a Board of Trustees comprised of 12 members appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate. The Board of Trustees for the Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation includes 5 trustees appointed by the President with Senate approval, 1 trustee who is the Secretary of the Interior, and 1 trustee who is the Secretary of Education. The Board of Trustees for the Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation consists of 5 trustees appointed by the President with Senate approval. The board also includes the Secretary of the Interior and the President of Portland State University as nonvoting members. Trustees serve a 6-year term, with exceptions for initial appointments designated by the President. Trustees appointed under subsection (b)(2)(A) and (b)(2)(C) serve 4 years, while those designated by the President under (b)(2)(A), (b)(2)(B), and (b)(2)(C) serve 6 years. Vacancy trustees serve the remainder of the predecessor's term and are appointed in the same manner. Trustees serve without pay. The Foundation's trustees serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel and subsistence expenses. The Foundation is located in Portland, Oregon. An Executive Director, appointed by the Board, serves as the chief executive officer and carries out the Foundation's functions under the Board's supervision. Compensation for the Executive Director is determined by the Board. The Executive Director shall be compensated at the rate specified for an employee in level IV of the Executive Schedule under section 5315 of title 5, United States Code. The Foundation aims to train Native American and Alaska Native tribal council members in self-government, promote understanding of tribal self-government in the US, address critical issues facing tribal governments, conduct tribal governance research, and provide educational outreach on tribal self-government. The Foundation, in consultation with the Institute, may conduct programs, activities, and services to carry out its purposes, including awarding scholarships, fellowships, internships, and grants. It may also organize national competitions to select recipients of these awards. Eligible individuals may receive scholarships, fellowships, internships, and grants from the Foundation. The Foundation offers scholarships, fellowships, internships, and grants to eligible individuals for study in tribal governance fields. Recipients are known as "Elizabeth Furse Scholars." Scholarships are awarded to undergraduate students pursuing careers in tribal governance or tribal public policy. Eligible individuals may receive payments under this Act. The Foundation may require reports from eligible individuals awarded scholarships under this Act, containing necessary information and filed at specified times. The Foundation may award fellowships to outstanding graduate students and faculty in fields related to tribal governance, public policy, law, or medicine. Internships may also be awarded to deserving individuals. Reports must be accompanied by a certificate of satisfactory progress from an official at the institution of higher education. The Foundation may award internships to deserving individuals for use in participating in Federal, State, and local agencies or major tribal governance organizations, as well as Native American and Alaska Native individuals for internships in public health or public policy organizations. Grants will be awarded to the Institute for various purposes including hosting expert panels on tribal governance issues, conducting policy research, and inviting policymakers to share experiences. The Foundation assists in developing a tribal governance research program at the Institute, determining program priorities and allocating funds accordingly. At least 50% of funds are designated for specific programs, while 20% is allocated to the Institute for subsections (h) and (i). The Foundation provides funding for a tribal governance research program at the Institute, with a 25% matching share required from non-Federal sources. Space at the Institute must be provided for the Executive Director and staff, with not more than 15% of funds used for salaries and administrative purposes. Establishment of Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Trust Fund. Establishment of the "Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Trust Fund" in the Treasury of the United States. The Fund will be administered by the Foundation and consist of appropriated amounts. The Secretary of the Treasury will invest the Fund assets in public debt securities with suitable maturities, bearing interest rates determined by the Secretary. The Secretary of the Treasury will invest the Fund assets in public debt securities with suitable maturities, bearing interest rates determined by the Secretary, yielding on outstanding marketable obligations of the United States of comparable maturity. The Foundation will use interest and earnings from the Fund to carry out the Act. The Government Accountability Office can audit the Foundation and Institute activities. Access to all relevant documents is granted for the audit. Administrative provisions are outlined in Section 9. The Foundation can appoint personnel and procure services as needed to carry out the Act, with limitations on compensation rates. Regulations can be promulgated as deemed necessary. The Foundation can promulgate regulations, accept gifts, use voluntary personnel, and enter into contracts to carry out the Act. The Board members can enter into contracts without a performance bond or other bond, and without regard to certain statutes, and make necessary expenditures. Authorization of appropriations to the Fund is set at $50,000,000.
